addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord,
e L. Burghley, Lord highe Treasuro
r
of England.

3 N
o
1590
M
r
Bodeleie from the
Hagh
.

page.lettertext:
fol.196r
May it please yo
r
good L. notw
t
standing
e
ill successe of
Count Maurice
in his last at-
tempt, I advertised yo
r
L.
e 28 of Oc
t
that I had resolved, to goe forward w
t
my
practise: and to send some person of purpose,
to viewe
e state of those places,
at I descri-
bed unto yo
w
, in my first information. He
that is to be imploied, shall be gotten in
Ze-
land
: and one of
e parties themselves by
whome this mater was disclosed unto me, is
already gone thither, to make his choise among
his frindes. I can not say upon know-
ledge,
at
e Count had any inkling, that her
Ma
tie
intended, to undertake
at enterprise:
nor that he thought to defeate it by way of
prevention. But his soddaine going thither,
before
e weaknes of
e place was fully disco-
vered, and his concealing of his purpose from
e
Councel of state
, w
t
other like conjectures,
might minister some occasion, to suspect his
proceeding. I writte yo
r
L. in my
last of
e grievous complaintes, that are made
by this people, because their trafficke into spaine
is impeached by her Ma
tie
. The towne of
Middlebourgh
hath sent often about it, to
e
Ge-
neral states
, and there are at this present,
that are newly come from thens, certaine cla-
morous marchants, whose reportes abroade, are
very lewde and maligne. Being spoken to by
them, to hold a good hand in their behalf, I
have told them of it roundly, and have signified
further, that
e Assembly heere of
e General
fol.196v
states, is
e chiefest cause, of all this troble
to their contrey. For to
e end there might be
some good order taken, aswell for their trafficke,
as for all other maters,
at rest undecided,
between her Ma
tie
and these Provinces, her Hig
nes
had bin pleased, at
e instant sute of themselves,
to send purposely hither, and to propose certaine
meanes, for a general redresse of all that ether
side complained. Howbeit not only
M
r
Wilkes
,
whome her Ma
tie
sent, to take their resolutions,
was dismissed, after 10 weekes attendance, w
t
out any answear, to any thing proposed: but for
e space of 10 weekes more, w
ch
are spent sins
he departed, they never yet vouchesafed to send
ether answear, or piece of any answear, or any
kinde of letter, whereby her Ma
tie
might conjecture
that they meant to give her satisfaction. To
reherse it all,
at was in talke between us, it is
but needelees to yo
r
L. Nevertheles because I
sawe by their answears,
at they were very
muche cloaked w
t
at opposition, I thought to
mention it unto yo
w
. They lette
me further understand,
at
e states are bent
out of hand, to send a couple into
England
, to
make remonstrance to her Ma
tie
of all
e dom-
mages done unto them. It is thought that
e
parties shall be
Silla
pensioner of
Amsterdame
,
and
Van der Werke
pensioner of Middlebourgh:
two of those
at beare
e greatest streake, in
e
meeting of
e states, and will take any paines,
to crosse her Ma
ties
proceedinges. As
farre as I can conceave, this stopping of their
trafficke, is a very ready meane, being folowed
fol.197r
effectually, to force them unto reason, in all
that is depending between her Hig
nes
and them.
For if they would be revenged, by seeking after
Fraunce
, it is not nowe to be done: and to
enter into treaty of accord w
t
e Enemie, while
her Ma
tie
is possessed, and in good assurance, of
her cautionarie townes, it is not thought they
will attempt, or can, if they would, obtene a
peace to their liking. It is an opinion
heere of many, and I see some tokens of likeli-
hood, that some kinde of answear will be fra-
med, to
be
o
r
last Propositions, and sent by
these Deputies, that shall come about their trafficke.
Having nothing els, to impart w
t
yo
r
L. I
take my humble leave. From
e Hage.
N
o
3 1590.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden
Tho. Bodley
